@witgo I'm not sure it is the correct semantics (@mateiz ?), but based on how we partition sequences, that is expected. We zip by partition (see below). #776 simply makes the way we partition NumericRange consistent with other sequences.

Btw, as we discussed in #776, there is currently a bug in Scala NumericRange[Double].take() (https://issues.scala-lang.org/browse/SI-8518), which is causing parallelize() on Double to be wrong. For the purpose of this discussion, let's just assume the following partitioning result on Double correct.

```
scala> sc.parallelize(1L to 2L,4).collectPartitions
res0: Array[Array[Long]] = Array(Array(), Array(1), Array(), Array(2))

scala> sc.parallelize(11 to 12,4).collectPartitions
res2: Array[Array[Int]] = Array(Array(), Array(11), Array(), Array(12))

scala> sc.parallelize((1D to 2D).by(0.2),4).collectPartitions
res1: Array[Array[Double]] = Array(Array(1.0), Array(1.2), Array(1.6), Array(1.8))
```

Speaking of current way of partitioning, the following result is also curious.

```
scala> sc.parallelize(1 to 3, 2).collectPartitions
res10: Array[Array[Int]] = Array(Array(1), Array(2, 3))
```

@witgo for sequences of the same size, we can get the same result as Scala zip, as long as we partition them in the same way. For sequences of different sizes (your example), our result will be different from Scala zip because of partitioning.
@tgravescs any thoughts around this, should I just close this pull request?

As I mentioned in the jira, I don't see value in this change - it is a corner case trying to save about 5 lines of straightforward code while adding to the public api

IMO this make things fragile.
First off, not MT safe.
Secondly does not handle corner cases - for example exception handling.
Ah, sorry, I was actually working on this in parallel: https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/806. Mind closing this PR and commenting on that one?
Merged build triggered.
Merged build triggered.
Merged build started.
Merged build started.
I also changed "distribution" to "binary package" here to make it more consistent with the wording on our website.

Do you mind elaborating on why it's a corner case?  My understanding is that Kryo is the right choice over Java serialization in 99% of cases, and any time somebody wants to use their own objects with Kryo serialization, they need something like those 8 lines of code.  I've had the opportunity to teach a bunch of people how to use Spark over the last few months and how to write those lines of code has come up almost every time.
Will follow up there, thanks
I was using distribution because the script that creates it is called `make-distribution.sh`.  Maybe that should be renamed.  Should I file a jira to rename that to `make-binary-package.sh`?

Ah, I see. We could rename it later but I'd make that low-priority (some users might be confused by the script being renamed). I'm also slightly concerned about calling it a distribution because it sounds like the same thing as a "Linux distribution" or "Hadoop distribution", which is usually a different version of the code.

I have elaborated in the jira, but I will repeat it again for clarity:

This is adding an api for a specific case - it assumes single serialization
type (kryoserializable).
The reduction in boilerplate is not high, neither is it doing so for
something tricky/implementation detail.

Particularly given stress of simplifying our api this is going the opposite
direction without sufficient value to justify it.
 On 17-May-2014 4:34 am, "Sandy Ryza" notifications@github.com wrote:

> Do you mind elaborating on why it's a corner case? My understanding is
> that Kryo is the right choice over Java serialization in 99% of cases, and
> any time somebody wants to use their own objects with Kryo serialization,
> they need something like those 8 lines of code. I've had the opportunity to
> teach a bunch of people how to use Spark over the last few months and how
> to write those lines of code has come up almost every time.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/apache/spark/pull/789#issuecomment-43388406
> .

Alternative to adding to `SparkContext`'s API, how about an API along the lines of:

```
Seq[Class[Any]] classes = ...
KryoRegistrator.enableKryoWithClasses(sc, classes)
```

The `enableKryoWithClasses` call would basically do the same thing as before but as a helper function.

@kanzhang 

```
scala> sc.parallelize((1D to 2D).by(0.2),4).collect
res0: Array[Double] = Array(1.0, 1.2, 1.6, 1.8)
```

```
scala> sc.parallelize((1D to 2D).by(0.2),5).collect
res5: Array[Double] = Array(1.0, 1.2, 1.4, 1.5999999999999999, 1.7999999999999998, 1.9999999999999998)
```

The first one should be wrong.
Jenkins, this is ok to test
